citations.narrative:
The facility has exceeded the maximum number of animals allowed under their license. The facility is approved for up to
100 animals but 179 animals were documented during the inspection.
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure that the facility and personnel possess adequate
facilities, employees and education to provide sufficient husbandry to the regulated animals. A licensee must obtain a new
license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand at any single point in time
during the period of licensure. The licensee must reapply for a license that properly reflects the number of regulated
animals under the license or reduce the number of regulated animals to a number which is under the maximum threshold
authorized under the current license.
To be corrected by November 3, 2023.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
Records of dispositions and animal inventory were not available for review at the time of inspection.
Failure to provide these documents hinders APHIS officials from tracking animals used in regulated activities to ensure
their humane care, use, and disposition. The licensee must allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept
by the AWA.
To be corrected by October 20, 2023.

The main show room of the facility has accumulations of bins and other objects crowding the space that prevents
adequate cleaning. The floor has accumulations of old bedding material and other debris scattered around.
These accumulations can attract insect and mammalian pests and pose disease hazards to the regulated animals. The
premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to facilitate the proper husbandry of the regulated animals.
To be corrected by October 25, 2023.

There are two different enclosures, each housing 11 spiny mice, that contain animals with injuries. Several mice have
reddened or scabbed areas on their tails as well as some that have injuries on their backs.
Housing animals at too high a density can cause compatibility issues. Housing incompatible animals together can lead to
injury or even death. The facility must ensure that animals housed together are compatible.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(i) 
   
Requirements and application 
The facility has exceeded the maximum number of animals allowed under their license. The facility is approved for up to 
100 animals but 179 animals were documented during the inspection. 
 
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure that the facility and personnel possess adequate 
facilities, employees and education to provide sufficient husbandry to the regulated animals. A licensee must obtain a new 
license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand at any single point in time 
during the period of licensure. The licensee must reapply for a license that properly reflects the number of regulated 
animals under the license or reduce the number of regulated animals to a number which is under the maximum threshold 
authorized under the current license. 
 
To be corrected by November 3, 2023. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
Records of dispositions and animal inventory were not available for review at the time of inspection.  
 
Failure to provide these documents hinders APHIS officials from tracking animals used in regulated activities to ensure 
their humane care, use, and disposition. The licensee must allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept 
by the AWA.  
 
To be corrected by October 20, 2023. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The main show room of the facility has accumulations of bins and other objects crowding the space that prevents 
adequate cleaning. The floor has accumulations of old bedding material and other debris scattered around.

These accumulations can attract insect and mammalian pests and pose disease hazards to the regulated animals. The 
premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to facilitate the proper husbandry of the regulated animals.  
 
To be corrected by October 25, 2023. 
3.133  Repeat
   
Separation. 
There are two different enclosures, each housing 11 spiny mice, that contain animals with injuries. Several mice have 
reddened or scabbed areas on their tails as well as some that have injuries on their backs.  
 
Housing animals at too high a density can cause compatibility issues. Housing incompatible animals together can lead to 
injury or even death. The facility must ensure that animals housed together are compatible. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
